pr_title: Add support for snapshot and restore to data streams

timeline.bodyText: I don't think we need the concrete instances of DataStream here? I think we should just track the IDs of data streams to snapshot here like we do for indices. Otherwise, we have to keep these in memory for the whole duration of the snapshot.
timeline.author: original-brownbear

timeline.bodyText: I would rather not add the data streams to the SnapshotInfo blobs. Adding them here, means that these blobs can get quite large and we load them in parallel in many occasions (e.g. SLM figuring out what snapshots to delete). These blobs really are designed as a lightweight thing, not as something to store data in. If we add to it we up the resource (memory+transfer) usage of our get snapshots APIs which is already problematic in some cases.
timeline.author: original-brownbear

replies.bodyText: Would just the data stream name ids be ok?
replies.author: martijnvg

replies.bodyText:
I'm assuming you want to add it to be able to get a list of data streams for each snapshot in the snapshot listing from the get snapshots API?
For that I think it's fine. Not great to add it here but I don't see an easy alternative to it right now and it's not a lot of data anyway if it's just the names.
For purposes of restoring I don't think we would need this (we can just inspect the cluster state we're restoring from there).
replies.author: original-brownbear

replies.bodyText:
Thanks @original-brownbear for review! I initially do it the way you proposed (storing data streams in global metadata) - metadataForSnapshot is already modified accordingl, it worked just fine and for sure was less intrusive change.
My concern with that was that on any restore with have to download whole state to examine it for data streams and that can be costly. Storing data streams ids would mitigate some of it, but still we would need whole global state if we want to restore any data stream.
Or do you think this should not be such big problem?
(I didn't really care for displaying it in get snapshots TBH, but it is nice touch)
replies.author: probakowski

replies.bodyText:
npnp @probakowski :)

Or do you think this should not be such big problem?

Yea this is irrelevant. Those few extra bytes to download won't hurt anyone for a rare action like restoring data streams :)

(I didn't really care for displaying it in get snapshots TBH, but it is nice touch)

Hmm, if we don't care about it all that much, we could even leave out the change to SnapshotInfo for step 1 I guess. It's certainly nice to save those bytes here and not add any format changes if we don't have to. But I'm fine adding the list of names as well if you think it's helpful for users.
replies.author: original-brownbear

timeline.bodyText: You have to make sure not to allow any specific data stream snapshotting as long as there's master nodes older than DATA_STREAMS_IN_SNAPSHOT in the cluster. Otherwise, if you have a master failover to an old version master the information about the data stream snapshots is just lost because it won't deserialize that part.
timeline.author: original-brownbear

timeline.bodyText: This looks broken, we should always be able to read global metadata (we always write at least a dummy instance of it to the repository). If we fail here, then that means the snapshot is corrupted and we should throw right away and can simplify the below code accordingly.
timeline.author: original-brownbear

replies.bodyText:
I followed SharedClusterSnapshotRestoreIT.testRestoreSnapshotWithCorruptedGlobalState. It targets situation when global metadata is broken, not empty.
It makes sense to me that even when global metadata is broken we should be able to restore indices and data for rescue purposes. If we throw here (as it was before) we can't do that even when we don't care about data streams. WDYT?
replies.author: probakowski

replies.bodyText:
Ah I see ... but then we should only try to load the global metadata if either includeGlobalState() or data streams have been requested for restore specifically?
That way we don't create some new weird half-working state where indices are restored but data streams aren't when both are requested. Also, we save loading the global metadata needlessly this way.
I guess that needs a data streams parameter on the restore request or at least a flag data streams yes/no?
I don't think we should introduce an API here that would return a 200 even though data streams couldn't be restored. No one ever looks at the logs :)
replies.author: original-brownbear

replies.bodyText:
Ok, I took another turn on that, storing data streams' names in userMeta (similarly as SLM stores policy name there).
It simplifies things greatly (no need to change Entry and its serialization etc) and saves us from loading global state on every restore (we need it only on restoring data streams).
It does enlarge SnapshotInfo, it should not be that bad though as they are only names not whole data streams.
Let me know what do you think?
